title: Crude's Strongest 3-Day Rally in 25 Years: 4 Momentum Picks
text:
Content preferences Done 
In a dramatic turn of events, energy investors swung from negative to a positive territory last week. Here’s what happened:When the commodity fell below $39 each barrel for the first time in more than six years early last week, the markets predicted a further slide. All the short sellers waited for the right moment to book profits. And then, from out of the blue, crude climbed more than 27% in the last three sessions, marking the largest winning streak in the last 25 years.The sudden spike points to some momentum in the commodity. So investors can try out a short-term play using a momentum strategy to add substantial returns to their portfolio. As a caveat, this is a purely speculative strategy and strictly not meant for the risk-averse players. After all, life is all about taking chances. Isn’t it? Momentum Looks Real The market got habituated to trickling crude prices for more than one year. When crude dipped below the $40-per-barrel mark last week, the commodity had witnessed an over 60% fall from mid 2014 when oil was trading above $100 each barrel that time. This was owing to plentiful supply of the commodity following the shale revolution, as U.S. shale producers went on a production spree by using fracking and horizontal drilling techniques. Moreover, the slowdown in the Chinese economy was also responsible for the crude freefall as the country is the second-largest consumer of the commodity in the world.In spite of the prolonged fall, WTI crude seems to have clung to its new-found momentum. The commodity surged more than 8% yesterday to close at $49.20 a barrel, the highest mark in the last six weeks. Following yesterday’s gain, crude surged more than 27% in the last three sessions.Let’s find the reasons for this sudden outperformance by the commodity when most of the analysts were expecting its price to go further down. To some extent we can say that the news of less oil pumped out in the U.S – as per Energy Information Administration (EIA) – along with the speculation that Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) might consider an output cut helped crude to gain this momentum. Less Production in the U.S.: In June, total pumped out crude in the U.S. was 9.3 million barrels of oil per day, which is roughly 100,000 barrels a day lower than what was estimated previously. On top that, June output was less than the prior month’s production.Lower utilization of rigs for drilling activities amid an unfavorable business scenario led to lower production. This is evident from Baker Hughes’ report which indicated that since last October, the total number of drilling rigs in the U.S. is down 58%. OPEC’s Expected Production Cut: A recent OPEC statement indicated that the organization is ready to call a meeting wherein the oil producing countries can hear each other out. This might be an indication that OPEC is considering a production cut amid plentiful supply of the commodity. Going Deep into the Analysis Of course news of lower U.S. production and OPEC’s expected production cut spread positive vibes. But what added momentum to crude is the story of short covering. By definition, short covering indicates the purchase of commodities which have already been sold short. This is usually done when prices witness an upward movement. Here, the short sellers were expecting crude price to fall and were eagerly waiting for the right moment to make profits. But all of a sudden oil started rising. Hence, to arrest losses the short sellers were forced to book profits by buying the commodity. As more short sellers booked profits, oil price surged more than 27% in the last three sessions.However, we need to mention that although crude price surged, the commodity’s price is still low. Crude closed at $49.20 per barrel yesterday, which is now more than 50% below the mid-2014 level. Refiners are still able to purchase crude at low costs to create refined petroleum products like gasoline, used as fuel for internal-combustion engines. Moreover, the news of oil price rise is good for oil drillers as their expected rig demand is positively correlated with crude prices. To say it in another way, the higher the price of oil, the more will exploration and production activities take place. Not only will step-up in activities bode well for the industry, these will automatically translate into greater rig demand. Energy investors stand to gain from both. 4 Momentum Picks The basic fundamental driving a momentum trader is an investing strategy that seeks to capitalize on market volatility. Once a trend is recognized, these investors anticipate it to continue in the same direction, backed by the momentum already behind it.So with the help of our new style score system, we have identified four energy stocks that have Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) or 2 (Buy) and Momentum Score of ‘A’ that have the maximum chances of riding on this crude momentum. Alon USA Energy Inc. ALJDallas, TX-based Alon USA Energy’s main operation includes refining of crude and then marketing refined products like gasoline, diesel fuel, jet fuel, petrochemicals, petrochemical feedstock, asphalt and other petroleum-based products. The company conducts its business in the Southwestern and South Central regions of the United States.It offers a great investment potential and can be an impressive choice for momentum investors, given its Momentum Score of “A” and Zacks Rank #1. Alon USA Energy reported a positive average earnings surprise of 41.42% for the trailing four quarters. Valero Energy Corporation VLOValero Energy Corporation owns and operates refineries in the United States and Canada with a combined throughput capacity of approximately two million BPD, making it one of the top refiners of petroleum products in the nation. Valero is also one of the leading retail operators in the country, with retail outlets in the United States and Canada under various brand names such as Diamond Shamrock, Ultramar, Valero, Beacon and Total.Investors can count on the stock because it has a Momentum Score of “A” and a Zacks Rank #2. Positive earnings estimate revisions are encouraging. Moreover, for the last four quarters, the company posted a positive average earnings surprise of 24.12%. Transocean Ltd. RIGSwitzerland-based Transocean is the world’s largest offshore drilling contractor and leading provider of drilling management services. With less oil being discovered on land and companies having to dig ever deeper to get to their reserves, Transocean is poised to benefit from a market with robust multi-year demand trends, given its technologically advanced and versatile drilling fleet.It is a solid bet with a Momentum Score of “A” and a Zacks Rank #2. On top of that, the average earnings beat for the last four quarters is 58.91%. Pacific Drilling SA PACDLuxembourg-based Pacific Drilling provides ultra-deepwater drilling services to oil and gas companies across the globe. Currently, it has a fleet of six operating drillships, five of which are under contract and one is gearing up for contract commencement. The company also has two drillships under construction.It is yet another stock to invest in given its Momentum Score of “A” and a Zacks Rank #2. During the trailing four quarters, the company’s average earnings surprise came at a positive 15.14%. Bottom Line Oil is slippery and we never know which way it might flow tomorrow. If as long as its prices keep rising, smart investors should build positions in the stocks mentioned above to ride on the momentum. Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research?
